title: 103_hr358
content:
The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the risks law enforcement officers face daily, the lack of support from the Federal Government, their role in combating drugs and crime, the rise in violent crime and drug use, and the high percentage of arrested individuals testing positive for drugs. The Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice of 1965 highlighted various issues affecting law enforcement, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. A comprehensive study on law enforcement issues, such as the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and crime control responsibilities, would help redefine relationships in the field. A comprehensive study on law enforcement issues, including the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers and crime control responsibilities, would help redefine relationships in the field. Establishment of the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" (referred to as the "Commission") with duties outlined. The Commission will study and recommend changes related to law enforcement agencies at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, and research/training status. The Commission will study equipment, resources, cooperation among law enforcement agencies, government responsibility, and the impact of the criminal justice system. They will consult with law enforcement officers and local officials. The Commission will consult with focus groups of law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information and advice on key law enforcement issues. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations appointed by various leaders in Congress and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members, including seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations appointed by leaders in Congress and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members, including individuals appointed by leaders in Congress and the President. This includes individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House of Representatives, and appointees by the Speaker, majority leader, minority leader, and President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President, including individuals from Federal law enforcement, Department of Justice, State or local government, and Members of the House and Senate. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President, including individuals from Federal law enforcement, Department of Justice, State or local government, and Members of the House and Senate. The Comptroller General serves in an advisory capacity and oversees the methodology of the Commission's study. The members select a chairperson from among themselves. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President, including individuals from various government agencies. The members select a chairperson from among themselves. Members shall receive no additional compensation but will be reimbursed for travel expenses. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested by the Commission. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and secure information from federal agencies. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. Additionally, the Commission can accept gifts and donations. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, donations, and use the United States mails in the same manner as other Federal agencies. SEC. 8. REPORT.

A report with the Commission's findings and legislative proposals must be submitted to Congress within eighteen months of the Commission's appointment.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION.

The Commission will dissolve sixty days after submitting its report.

SEC. 10. REPEALS. Title XXXIV of the Crime Control Act of 1990 and title II, section 211 B of the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1991 are repealed.
